paragraphs.text:
%md
**Clustering of Malnutrition and Socio-Economic Factors**


                 **Introduction**

The purpose of this research is to replicate part of research performed by Nair et al. (2017) [1]
								 to cluster states within India based on factors impacting childhood malnutrition. Nair et al. [1] highlighted that 
								 there is a lack of research and application of data mining and machine learning in the field of childhood malnutrition. 
								 Additionally, the Indian government relies on geographical clusters (ie. states) to determine policy on malnutrition 
								 and Nair et al. [1] wanted thir research to focus on clustering variables from DHS data to cluster different states 
								 together. This can help the Indian government in devising policies to reduce malnutrition targetted at states with 
								 similar causes of malnutrition. Another important research work by Onda et al. (2014) [2] also performed cluster 
								 analysis on 156 countries for water sanitation using factors highlighted in previous research to have significant 
								 impact on water sanitation. 
Therefore this project has replicated these 2 papers to find groups in data about 
								 prevalance of childhood malnutrition and other socio-economic factors such as  maternal health, women's status and 
								 education, that have been shown by precious literature to have strong influence on childhood malnutrition [3-6]. 
								 Research done by Kumanr et al. [7] provides the technical guidelines to conduct cluster analysis on a large dataset 
								 using Spark MLlib.
								 

**Methodology**


								 The data used in this project is the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) data [8] collected over the the period of 2008 
								 - 2016 from over 55 countries in 5 continents. The DHS data provides wide range of monitoring and impact evaluation 
								 indicators (1,000+ features) in the areas of population, health, and nutrition. The variables of interest for this 
								 projects were measures related to malnutrition:
1) Height for Age (HAZ): -1 < HAZ < -1.9 = Mild ; -2 < HAZ < -2.9 = 
								 Moderate Stunting; -3 < HAZ = Severe Stunting [9,10]
2) Weight for Age Z score (WAZ):  -1 < WAZ < -1.9 = Mild ; -2 < 
								 WAZ < -2.9 = Moderate Wasting; -3 < HAZ = Severe Wasting [9,10]
3) Weight for Height (WHZ): -1 < WHZ < -1.9 = Mild ; 
								 -2 < WHZ < -2.9 = Moderate; -3 < WHZ = Severe [9,10]

Other variables of interest are regarding: age of women, 
								 financial status in the family, size of the household, literacy of women, women employment and marital status. 
The 
								 following steps are followed:

1) Data quality checks are done as per guidelines given by Rattenbury et al. (2017) 
								 [11]
2) Data is cleaned and prepared.
2) Variables related to women's health and status are used to cluster dataset 
								 using Spark MLLIB [12]. Within Set Sum of Square Errors are calculated to idnetify the idean k number of clusters
3) 
								 The proportional methodolgy from Nair et al. [1] is replicated to identify the which cluster a country belongs to based 
								 on identifying in which clusters do the the largest proportion of data points from a particular country fall under. \
								 n
**Data Gathering**


								 The data was downloaded from DHS website [8]. This data was only available at SPSS, SAS or STATA files.ipynb notebooks 
								 were written to convert these files to a csv format. These files were uploaded for Google Drive and then %wget codes 
								 were written to download tar.gzip file from Shared Drive [13].
								 


**Basic observations about the structure of DHS data**


								 For initial observations, the DHS datasets for Angola (2016), Albania (2008) and Nepal (2011) were observed. All the 
								 records in individual files have the same fields, however when the schema for 3 DHS datasets from 3 different years are 
								 compared, it can be seen that there are commonalities between some variables across all 3 datasets (ex: v000, v001, 
								 v002 etc.), however there are other variables that are not found consistently across all datasets. (ex: s646x is 
								 available in Angola 2016 dataset but is not found in others). Therefore, it is important to read the DHS Manuals [14] 
								 to understand what are the variable labels and which variables are common amongst the different datasets, which is how 
								 we can access the same fields across records. The records are in a CSV format and a sophisticated parsing logic is not 
								 required to seprate the records from one another. The data fields are a mixture of combined integer and string 
								 types.The relationship between records and the records fields is singualar. The DHS data represent survey data that was 
								 collected in different countries during different years and contains information about children and women in a 
								 household. These records are homogenous, ie. represent the record for each child from a household.

Onda et al. 
								 (2014) uses past research to identify factors that impact public water sanitation, which are then included in a cluster analysis. Based on this strategy, research was done to identify socio-economic factors related to women's health in the country that impact childhood malnutrition [3 - 6]. The variables are selected from all the DHS dataset below and merged into a single dataset 
Total number of records in the merged dataset = 950,849. The final dataset includes data from 5 continents: Africa, Asia, North America, South America and Europe, and include data from 55 countries between the years of 2008-2017. The top 3 countries with the most records are provided by countries: India (259,609), Nigeria (60,129) & Afghanistan (32,712). The countries with the leaast records are: Albania (1,616), Sao Tome & Principe (1,931) and Guyana (2,178) . The largest number of data records come from the continent of Africa (458,397) and the least number of records come from Europe (4,813).

**Assessment of Data Accurary**

***caseid (Case Identification) & midx***
Case identification is a unique identifier for each respondent in household and midx is the index of the birth history[14,15]. There are no records where caseid = null. There are 3152 values where midx = null from Bangladesh_Child_BDKR72FL_2014.csv file and these records are removed from the dataset.

***Variable v007 (Year of Interview)*** 
None of the records have this variable as null. Since the project is investigating the data collected for DHS datasets year 2008 - 2017, we don't expect the variable v007 to be between 2008 +/- 2 years and 2017. However, when the years are assessed, we can see years including: 1394, 2003, 2008, 2067, 2068, 2073. Further analysis was done to identify the countries and filenames from which they years of interview are being identified. After further research these were the conclusions made to clean the data:
1) Year 1394 is being reported fom Afghanistan from the file: Afghanistan_Child_AFKR70FL_2015.csv. After research, it is concluded that DHS is deriving the year from Afghan Calendar and that 1394 in Afghan Calendar --> 2015 in Gregorian Calendar [16]. 
2) Year 2003 is being reported from Ethiopia from the file: Ethiopia_Child_ETKR61FL_2011.csv. After research, it is concluded that DHS is deriving the year from Ethiopian Calendar and that 2003 in Ethiopian Calendar --> 2011 in Gregorian Calendar [17]. 
3) 2067 and 2068  years are being reported from Nepal from file: Nepal_Child_NPKR60FL_2011.csv, year 2073 from file: Nepal_Child_NPKR7HFL_2016.csv. It is concluded that the years are Nepali Calendar, such that 2067 year in Nepali Calendar --> 2010 in Gregorian Calendar [18].  
Code is written to update the above years to Gregorian Calendar. This code was further validated to ensure that the year of interview was updated correctly. 
After cleaning the data it is evident that the largest # of records have been collected from the years: 2015, 2016 and 2013.

***Variable v012 (current age of respondent in years)***
There were no null values in this variable, ie. The age of the respondent was always available. The minimum and maximum age of the respondent was 13 and 49 years old respectively. The average age of the respondent is 28.42 years. 


***Variable v015 (Result of individual interview)***
Code 1 represents a completed interview [14, 15]. All records in the dataset include completed interviews.

***Variable v026 (De facto place of residence)***
According to the DHS Manual [14, 15], the labels for this variable represent:
0 =  Capital, large city
1 =  Small city
2 = Town
3  = Countryside
9 = Missing
This is a categorical variable with majority of the values = null (837,816). Therefore it was decided to drop this variable from further analysis.  

***Variable v133 (Education in single years)***
There are 16,260 null records which are removed from the dataset.
The minimum, average and maximum years in education is  0, 2.85 and 24 years respectively.

***Variables v136 (Number of household members (listed))***
This variable is the total number of household members that are the usual residents plus the number of visitors who slept in the house the previous night [14, 15]. There are no null values. The average number of household members noted was 6.8 members.

***Variables v155 (Literacy)***
According to the DHS manual [14, 15], the variable labels represent the following:
0 = Cannot read at all
1  = Able to read only parts of sentence
2  = Able to read whole sentence
3  = No card with required language
4  = Blind/visually impaired
 (m) 9  = Missing
There are 55,901 records that are null which are removed. This variable is converted to a binary field: v155_literate where labels (0, 3 and 4) are recoded as 0, whereas labels (1,2) are recoded as 1. 55.5% of the recoded values fall under the literate category.

***Variable v190 (Wealth index)***
There are no null records. According to the DHS manual, this variable is ordinal and the labels for this variable are:
1 = Poorest
2 = Poorer
3 = Middle
4 = Richer
5= Richest
The min, avg and max is : 1, 2.7 and 5 respectively. Therefore, the average wealth index of the households in the final dataset is between the continuum of Poorer and Middle.

***Variable v201 (Total children ever born)***
There are no null records. The min, avg and max is 1, 3.4 and 18 children.

***Variable v212 (Age of respondent at first birth)***
There are no null records. The average age at first birth is 20 years. 

***Variable v228 (Ever had a terminated pregnancy)***
There are null records which are removed from the dataset. This is a binary variable where 0 = no and 1 = yes.

***Variable v445 (Body mass index)***
According to DHS manual [14, 15], this variable needs to be divided by 100 to receive BMI. However, majority of the records are null, therefore, this variable is dropped.

***Variable v447a (Women’s age in years)***
The majority of the records are null, therefore, this variable is dropped.

***Variable v501 (Current marital status)***
According to DHS manual [8] the variables mean:
0 =  Never in union
1  = Married
2 = Living with partner
3 = Widowed
4 = Divorced
5 = No longer living together/separated
9 = Missing
This variable is converted to binary variable v501_married_partner where fields 1 & 2 = 1, and 0,3, 4 and 5 = 0 because k-means algorithm cannot use categorical variables [7]. Majority of the respondents in the dataset are either married or living with a partner (92.6%).

***Variable v731 (Respondent worked in last 12 months)***
Records with null values are removed. According to DHS manual [14, 15], the fields are:
0 = No
1 = in past year
2 = Currently working
3=  Have a job, but on leave last 7 days
This categorical variable is converted to binary variable v731_working where field, 0 = 0 and 1,2 & 3= 1 because k-means algorithm cannot use categorical variables [7]. Majority of the women in the dataset were employed in some form in the past year (55.1%)

***Variable b4 (Sex of child)***
According to DHS manual [14 ,15], 1 = male and 2 =female. There is new variable create b4_male where 1 = 1 and 2 =0.  The male to female ratio in this dataset is balanced (338738:325031)

***Variable b5 (Child is alive)***
B5 = 0 means that child is dead [14, 15]. For this project, the dataset with only alive children were included (ie. B5 =1). 

***Variable b8 (Current age of child) in years***
The average age of child in this dataset is 1.95 years with a min and max age of less than 1 year and 4 years respectively.

***Variable hw70 (Height/Age standard deviation (new WHO), Variable hw71 (Weight/Age standard deviation (new WHO) and Variable hw72 (Weight/Height standard deviation (new WHO)***
Records are removed where all 3 of these variables are null.
If either the weight or the height of the child is missing then all of the above measures are set to the missing code 9999 or 99999. If either the height or the weight is outside of the acceptable range for the calculation of these measures then all of the above measures is set to code 9998 or 99998.

All three of hese variable show normal distribution.

***Variable hw73 (BMI standard deviation (new WHO))***
The null records are removed from the dataset. The dataset is normally distributed.

**Further Exploratory Analysis**
HAZ and WAZ are highly correlated (corr = 0.641).
HAZ and BMI are not strongly correlated (corr = -0.252)
As already discussed, stunting is defined as HAZ <= -2. Three countries with the highest percentage of stunting are: Timor-Leste, Guatemala and Pakistan.
Wasting is defined as WAZ <= -2. Three countries with the highest percentage of wasting are: Timor-Leste, Niger and India.

**Clustering**
The following variables are used to perform K-Means clustering on using the Spark MLlib library [12]. 
"v012", "v133", "v136", "v155_literate", "v190", "v201", "v212", "v501_married_partner", "v731_working", "b4_male", "b8"
According to Kumari et al. [7], they performed K-Means at increasing number of k clusters to calculate Within Set Sum of Squared Error (WSSSE), which are plotted against the number of clusters to identify the optimal number of k clusters. Ideally, WSSSE should have been calculated for a larger range of k clusters, but for this project, WSSSE was calculated for 5 to 25 at an interval of 10 clusters. Additionally, running K-means clustering for several clusters took 3+ hours to run on DSW. Therefore, for demonstration purposes, datasets from the countries with highest rates of stunting and wasting: Time Leste, Guatemala, Pakistan, Benin and Niger were selsected to undgergo K-means. Using this strategy we selected 15 number of cluster becasue in the scree plot there is an elbow generated at k =15. 
Cluster centres show that the records belonging to 14th cluster have the oldest women, while the 2nd cluster have the youngest women; 13th cluster have the least educated women and 7th cluster have the most educated women. Similarly, if future research can be done, the results need to be further analyzed at a much granular level. In reality a lot more cluster numbers should have been tested for the entire dataset. Finally, which country belonged to which cluster can also be identified using the methodology of proportions used by Nair et al [1]. This was also not performed due to performance issues in DSW.

paragraphs.text:
%sh
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_A.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_B.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_C.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_DE.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/

tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_G2.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_HI.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_I2.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_I3.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_I4.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_IJK.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/
tar -zxvf '/resources/data/TAR_LM.tar.gz' -C /resources/data/

//create dataframe nepaldf for Nepal 2011 dataset
var nepaldf = spark.read
         .format("csv")
         .option("header", "true") //reading the headers
         .option("mode", "DROPMALFORMED")
         .option("inferSchema", "true") 
         .load(nepal)
         
nepaldf.printSchema()

paragraphs.text:
%md
***Merging Datasets to create a final dataset that has variables of interest***

msg.data: Merging Datasets to create a final dataset that has variables of interest

paragraphs.text:
//Create a list of files for the directory TAR_A and filter for DHS data based on filename and type
import java.io.File
val file = new File("/resources/data/")
val fileList = file.listFiles.filter(_.isFile)
    .filter(_.getName.endsWith(".csv")).filter(_.getName.contains("Child"))
    .map(_.getPath).toList

//Select variables of interest from research papers [4-7]

//Create an empty dataframe with schema
val caseid = $"caseid".string       //"Case Identification"
val midx = $"midx".int      //"Index to Birth History          
val v007 = $"v007".int       //"Year of interview"
val v012 = $"v012".int      //"Respondent's current age"
val v015 = $"v015".int      //"Result of individual interview"
val v026 = $"v026".string       //"De facto place of residence"
val v133 = $"v133".int      //"Education in single years"
val v136 = $"v136".int      //“Number of household members (listed)
val v155 = $"v155".int      //“Literacy”
val v190 = $"v190".int      //“Wealth index”
val v201 = $"v201".int      //“Total children ever born”
val v212 = $"v212".int      //“Age of respondent at first birth”
val v228 = $"v228".int      //“Ever had a terminated pregnancy”
val v445 = $"v445".int      //“Body mass index”
val v447a = $"v447a".int        //“Women's age in years (from household questionna”
val v501 = $"v501".int      //“Current marital status”
val v731 = $"v731".int      //“Respondent worked in last 12 months”
val b4 = $"b4".int      //“Sex of child”
val b5 = $"b5".int      //“Child is alive”
val b8 = $"b8".int      //“Current age of child (in months)
val hw70 = $"hw70".int      //“Height/Age standard deviation (new WHO)”
val hw71 = $"hw71".string	//“Weight/Age standard deviation (new WHO)”
val hw72 = $"hw72".string       //“Weight/Height standard deviation (new WHO)”
val hw73 = $"hw73".string       //“BMI standard deviation (new WHO)”
val filename = $"filename".string     //"filename"
val countries = $"countries".string     //"country"


import org.apache.spark.sql.types.StructType
val mySchema = StructType(caseid :: midx :: v007 :: v012 :: v015 :: v026 :: v133 :: v136 ::
v155 :: v190 :: v201 :: v212 :: v228 :: v445 :: v447a :: 
v501 :: v731 :: b4 :: b5 :: b8 :: hw70 :: hw71 :: hw72 :: hw73 :: filename :: countries :: Nil)
import org.apache.spark.sql.Row
var unionDF = spark.createDataFrame(sc.emptyRDD[Row], mySchema)
 
 
 for (f <- fileList) {
    var df= spark.read
         .format("csv")
         .option("header", "true") //reading the headers
         .option("mode", "DROPMALFORMED")
         .option("inferSchema", "true") 
         .load(f)
         .withColumn("filename",lit(f.split('/')(3)))
         .withColumn("countries",lit(f.split('/')(3).split('_')(0)))
        
    //All variable headers should be lowercase
    val cols = df.columns.map(c => s"$c as ${c.toLowerCase}")
    val df1= df.selectExpr(cols:_*)
    
    var newdf = df1.select("caseid", "midx", "v007", "v012", "v015", "v026", "v133", "v136", "v155"
    , "v190", "v201", "v212", "v228", "v445", "v447a","v501", "v731", "b4", "b5", "b8", "hw70", "hw71", "hw72", "hw73", "filename", "countries")

    unionDF = unionDF.unionAll(newdf)
    
  }

//Create a table
unionDF.createOrReplaceTempView("unionDF")

%md 
Total number of records in the merged dataset = 950,849. The final dataset includes data from 5 continents: Africa, Asia, North America, South America and Europe, and include data from 55 countries between the years of 2008-2017.
The top 3 countries with the most records are provided by countries: India (259,609), Nigeria (60,129) & Afghanistan (32,712).
The countries with the leaast records are: Albania (1,616), Sao Tome & Principe (1,931) and Guyana (2,178)
The largest number of data records come from the continent of Africa (458,397) and the least number of records come from Europe (4,813).

The top 3 countries with the most records are provided by countries: India (259,609), Nigeria (60,129) & Afghanistan (32,712).
The countries with the leaast records are: Albania (1,616), Sao Tome & Principe (1,931) and Guyana (2,178)
The largest number of data records come from the continent of Africa (458,397) and the least number of records come from Europe (4,813).

%sql
SELECT T1.countries, ROUND((T1.COUNT_OF_NEG2HAZ/T2.COUNT_OF_HAZ)*100,2) AS PERC_STUNTING
FROM
(SELECT countries, count(*) AS COUNT_OF_NEG2HAZ
FROM unionDF1
WHERE hw70_dec <= -2
GROUP BY countries) T1
LEFT JOIN 
(SELECT countries, count(*) AS COUNT_OF_HAZ
FROM unionDF1
GROUP BY countries) T2
ON T1.countries = T2.COUNTRIES
ORDER BY PERC_STUNTING DESC
LIMIT 10

paragraphs.text:
%md
**K-Means Clustering**

K-means clustering on DSW is very slow on such a large dataset (3+ hours to run a loop for different numbers of k). Therefore to demonstrate how k-means would work, I am taking a subset of data for the countries with the top stunting and wasting rates: Timor Leste, Niger, Guatemala, Pakistan and Benin.

msg.data:
K-Means Clustering

K-means clustering on DSW is very slow on such a large dataset (3+ hours to run a loop for different numbers of k). Therefore to demonstrate how k-means would work, I am taking a subset of data for the countries with the top stunting and wasting rates: Timor Leste, Niger, Guatemala, Pakistan and Benin.

paragraphs.text:
//Create a dataframe for 3 selected variables that are to be included in the clustering model
val rdd_df = sqlContext.sql("select countries, Continent, v012, v133, v136, v155_literate, v190, v201, v212, v501_married_partner, v731_working, b4_male, b8, hw70_dec, hw71_dec, hw72_dec, hw73_dec from unionDF1 where countries in ('TimorLeste','Niger', 'Guatemala', 'Pakistan','Benin')")

msg.data: rdd_df: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [countries: string, Continent: string ... 15 more fields]

paragraphs.text: rdd_df.printSchema()

//import and use Vector Assembler to create Column: Features
import org.apache.spark.ml.feature.VectorAssembler
import org.apache.spark.ml.linalg.Vectors

val assembler = new VectorAssembler()
  .setInputCols(Array("v012", "v136", "v155_literate", "v190", "v201", "v212", "v501_married_partner", "v731_working", "b4_male", "b8"))
  .setOutputCol("features")
  
//Output includes "features" column
val output = assembler.transform(rdd_df)

//Create an empty dataframe with schema
val countries = $"countries".string       //"Countries"
val Continent = $"Continent".string     //"Countinent"
val v012 = $"v012".int		//"current age of respondent in years"
val v133 = $"v133".int      //"Education in single years"          
val v136 = $"136".int      //“Number of household members (listed)"
val v155_literate = $"v155_literate".int        //Literate
val v190 = $"v190".int       //Wealth index
val v201 = $"v201".int      //Total children ever born
val v212 = $"v212".int      //age of respondent at first birth
val v501_married_partner = $"v501_married_partner".int      //currenty marital status
val v731_working = $"v731_working".int      //Respondent worked in last 12 months
val b4_male = $"b4_male".int        //Sex of the child
val b8 = $"b8".int      //Age of the child
val hw70_dec = $"hw70_dec".int      //Height/Age SD (new WHO)
val hw71_dec = $"hw71_dec".int      //Weight/Age SD (new WHO)
val hw72_dec = $"hw72_dec".int      //Weight/Height SD (new WHO)
val hw73_dec = $"hw73_dec".int      //BMI SD (new WHO)
val prediction = $"prediction".int 	//"prediction"
val number_of_clusters = $"number_of_clusters".int //"Number of clusters"
val WSSSE_val = $"WSSSE_val".int    //WSSSE score

import org.apache.spark.sql.types.StructType

val mySchema = StructType(countries :: Continent :: v012 :: v133 :: v136 :: v155_literate :: v190 :: v201 :: v212 :: v501_married_partner :: v731_working :: b4_male :: b8 :: hw70_dec :: hw71_dec :: hw72_dec :: hw73_dec :: prediction :: number_of_clusters :: WSSSE_val :: Nil)

import org.apache.spark.sql.Row

var unionDFfeatures = spark.createDataFrame(sc.emptyRDD[Row], mySchema)

//Re-running the cluster for optimal # of clusters
val kmeans = new KMeans().setK(15).setSeed(1L)
val model = kmeans.fit(output)
val predictions = model.transform(output)
val WSSSE = model.computeCost(output)

%md

**Bibliography**
[1] A. A. Nair, D. Gupta, S. Khare, D. M. Gopalkrishna, and A. Jyotishi. “Characteristics and causes of malnutrition across Indian states: A cluster analysis based on Indian Demographic and Health Survey Data”, in IEEE Conference on Advances in Computing, 2017

[2] K. Onda, J. Crocker, G. L. Kayser, and J. Bartram. "Country clustering applied to the water and sanitation sector: A new tool with potential applications in research and policy", *International Journal of Applied Hygiene and Environmental Health*, vol. 217, pp. 379-385, 2014.

[3] C. Altare, T. D. Delbiso, and D. Guha-Sapir. “Child wasting in emergency pockets: A meta-analysis of small-scale surveys from Ethiopia”, *International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health*, vol. 13(178), pp. 1-15, 2016

[4] D. Balk, A. Storeygard, M. Levy, J. Gaskell, M. Sharma, and R. Flor. “Child hunger in the developing world: An analysis of environmental and social correlates”, *Food Policy*, vol. 30, pp. 584-611, 2005
